title: FedRAMP Compliance Basics

content.content: FedRAMP compliance is our license to work with federal agencies. As a 6-person team, everyone plays a part in maintaining our LI-SaaS authorization.

content.title: What Compliance Means for Your Role

items: **Pete and Savvy**: Manage technical compliance - scans, POA&Ms, AWS configuration
**Dave and Shelly**: Understand compliance impact on business decisions and customer conversations
**ScaleSec**: Help maintain security posture and prepare audit evidence
**Everyone**: Follow security procedures - one mistake can jeopardize our authorization

content.content: Before making any system change, ask: "Does this affect our FedRAMP boundary?"

items: Making changes without updating documentation
Missing vulnerability remediation deadlines
Forgetting monthly scanning and POA&M updates
Poor evidence organization during audits
Adding systems or data types without updating authorization boundary

content.content: When in doubt, ask Pete or Savvy before making changes.

items: Vulnerability scanning with SCAP-validated tools
POA&M updates and reviews
Continuous monitoring report
Evidence collection
**Critical (CVSS 9.0+) internet-facing**: 15 days
**High-Risk**: 30 days
**Moderate-Risk**: 90 days
**Low-Risk**: 180 days
**CISA KEV**: Follow catalog dates
New AWS service: Update SSP and add to scanning
Architecture changes: Update diagrams and monthly report
New team members: Background checks and training
Security incidents: Document and update POA&M if needed

content.content: Document all system changes, security events, access changes, compliance activities, and customer-impacting events.
For retention requirements, refer to our Documentation Retention Policy. AWS handles most retention automatically.

items: Be honest and direct - say "I don't know" rather than guess
Stick to facts about what we do, not future plans
Reference documentation when possible
Stay in scope - only discuss AWS and Google Drive

content.content: Good evidence organization prevents findings. Label everything clearly with timestamps.
Monthly vulnerability management cycle: Discover → Prioritize → Remediate → Validate → Document
AWS native tools handle scanning. Our job is responding quickly and documenting thoroughly.

keyTakeaways: Everyone has a role in maintaining our LI-SaaS FedRAMP authorization
Vulnerability remediation deadlines are strict: 15 days for critical internet-facing, 30/90/180 for high/moderate/low
Monthly scanning and POA&M updates are mandatory
Document everything - changes, incidents, and remediation actions

quiz.question: A critical vulnerability (CVSS 9.5) is found on our internet-facing load balancer. How many days do we have to remediate it?
